title: 30s lagspike after `Persisted trie from memory database`
body:
Every couple days, there is `Persisted trie from memory database` from Geth, and after that comes a crazy lagspike >30s spanning several slots.

⚠️ During this lagspike, attached beacon node validator duties cannot be reliably performed, as the beacon node relies on EL (Geth) to determine whether a block is valid.

Note that the spec defines an 8s timeout to both `engine_newPayload` and `engine_forkchoiceUpdated`: https://github.com/ethereum/execution-apis/blob/main/src/engine/shanghai.md#engine_newpayloadv2

It would be great if Geth would reply with `SYNCING / ACCEPTED` in case the timeout is about to be reached, instead of replying with nothing. This way, the BN knows what's going on instead of degrading the EL connection.

Even better would be if Geth could still process `engine_newPayload` and `engine_forkchoiceUpdated` messages during this persist operation. As in, process them far enough to issue a final validity verdict. Or, obviously fixing the lag spike altogether :-)

```
rocketpool_eth1        | DEBUG[08-23|03:24:58.578] Served eth_syncing                       conn=172.18.0.3:45478 reqid=78090  duration="92.747µs"
rocketpool_eth1        | DEBUG[08-23|03:24:58.580] Served eth_getBlockByNumber              conn=172.18.0.3:45478 reqid=78091  duration="313.533µs"
rocketpool_eth1        | DEBUG[08-23|03:24:59.406] Served eth_getBlockByNumber              conn=172.18.0.5:35040 reqid=142469 duration="760.936µs"
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-23|03:25:00.792] Persisted trie from memory database      nodes=14,979,155 size=3.65GiB time=2m39.181582629s gcnodes=69,672,895 gcsize=26.10GiB gctime=10m2.499724637s livenodes=422,719 livesize=152.62MiB

rocketpool_eth1        | DEBUG[08-23|03:25:00.823] Served engine_forkchoiceUpdatedV2        conn=172.18.0.5:34914 reqid=142463 duration=26.49394218s
rocketpool_eth1        | WARN [08-23|03:25:00.824] Forkchoice requested unknown head        hash=a90265..533878
rocketpool_eth1        | DEBUG[08-23|03:25:00.824] Served engine_forkchoiceUpdatedV2        conn=172.18.0.5:35000 reqid=142467 duration=10.012106712s
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-23|03:25:01.035] Imported new potential chain segment     number=17,974,705 hash=a90265..533878 blocks=1 txs=134 mgas=13.443 elapsed=211.658ms    mgasps=63.514  dirty=195.87MiB

rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-23|03:25:01.317] Imported new potential chain segment     number=17,974,706 hash=22b056..a2c717 blocks=1 txs=128 mgas=12.818 elapsed=271.097ms    mgasps=47.284  dirty=196.85MiB

rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-23|03:25:01.891] Extend chain                             add=2 number=17,974,706 hash=22b056..a2c717
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-23|03:25:01.922] Chain head was updated                   number=17,974,706 hash=22b056..a2c717 root=58a9a0..842221 elapsed=31.173883ms

```

```
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-26|20:04:22.343] Persisted trie from memory database      nodes=15,522,470 size=3.77GiB time=2m41.777937169s gcnodes=73,094,369 gcsize=27.43GiB gctime=10m44.159144046s livenodes=437,477 livesize=158.12MiB
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-26|20:04:22.343] Imported new potential chain segment     number=18,001,105 hash=5c33e5..2b8433 blocks=1 txs=121 mgas=15.993 elapsed=32.698s      mgasps=0.489   dirty=201.88MiB

rocketpool_eth1        | WARN [08-26|20:04:22.362] Forkchoice requested unknown head        hash=73fd7c..2ba967
rocketpool_eth1        | DEBUG[08-26|20:04:22.362] Served engine_forkchoiceUpdatedV2        conn=172.18.0.5:46500 reqid=34949  duration=7.739647994s
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-26|20:04:22.643] Imported new potential chain segment     number=18,001,106 hash=73fd7c..2ba967 blocks=1 txs=154 mgas=22.393 elapsed=282.763ms    mgasps=79.195  dirty=203.69MiB
rocketpool_eth1        | DEBUG[08-26|20:04:22.644] Served engine_newPayloadV2               conn=172.18.0.5:46424 reqid=34948  duration=16.461765452s
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-26|20:04:22.802] Imported new potential chain segment     number=18,001,107 hash=19a72c..6ceeac blocks=1 txs=113 mgas=9.892  elapsed=155.892ms    mgasps=63.457  dirty=204.38MiB
rocketpool_eth1        | DEBUG[08-26|20:04:22.803] Served engine_newPayloadV2               conn=172.18.0.5:46520 reqid=34952  duration=366.493227ms
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-26|20:04:23.270] Extend chain                             add=2 number=18,001,107 hash=19a72c..6ceeac
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-26|20:04:23.283] Chain head was updated                   number=18,001,107 hash=19a72c..6ceeac root=af5147..21c9b1 elapsed=13.26957ms
rocketpool_eth1        | DEBUG[08-26|20:04:23.283] Served engine_forkchoiceUpdatedV2        conn=172.18.0.5:46532 reqid=34953  duration=16.74526ms
```

#### System information

Geth version: `ethereum/client-go:v1.12.2`
CL client & version: e.g. `statusim/nimbus-eth2:multiarch-v23.7.0`
OS & Version: Linux
Hardware: Rock 5B 16GB RAM (Rocketpool setup with Docker)

#### Expected behaviour

- `engine_forkchoiceUpdated` and `engine_newPayload` should always be answered within the 8s spec defined timeout.
- Maintenance tasks should not lead to multi-slot lagspikes as it interferes with validator duties.

#### Actual behaviour

- 30s processing times for `engine_forkchoiceUpdated` and `engine_newPayload` after `Persisted trie from memory database`.


#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

- Run Geth :-)
- `--log.vmodule rpc=5` to see RPC response times. The `Imported new potential chain segment` log's `elapsed` also reflects the lagspike though.

Also, this is on LevelDB. If resyncing can improve this, would be great to know as well.

```
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-19|14:20:02.232] Starting pprof server                    addr=http://127.0.0.1:6060/debug/pprof
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-19|14:20:02.247] Starting Geth on Ethereum mainnet... 
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-19|14:20:02.251] Maximum peer count                       ETH=25 LES=0 total=25
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-19|14:20:02.252] Smartcard socket not found, disabling    err="stat /run/pcscd/pcscd.comm: no such file or directory"
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-19|14:20:02.256] Set global gas cap                       cap=50,000,000
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-19|14:20:02.257] Initializing the KZG library             backend=gokzg
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-19|14:20:02.437] Allocated trie memory caches             clean=614.00MiB dirty=1024.00MiB
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-19|14:20:02.860] Using leveldb as the backing database 
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-19|14:20:02.860] Allocated cache and file handles         database=/ethclient/geth/geth/chaindata cache=2.00GiB handles=524,288
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-19|14:20:06.185] Using LevelDB as the backing database 
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-19|14:20:06.295] Opened ancient database                  database=/ethclient/geth/geth/chaindata/ancient/chain readonly=false
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [08-19|14:20:07.181] Initialising Ethereum protocol           network=1 dbversion=8
```

I'm a bit reluctant to go too deeply into this issue because it might not really be relevant short-/mid term. Pebble is generally more performant than LevelDB, so we definitely recommend running with that. Our new path-based scheme is also a lot more performant and does less disk overheads (i.e. it doesn't have the entire trie persisting mechanism at all).

If you can afford it, my recommendation would be to try running the master branch with `--state.scheme=path` and `--db.engine=pebble` (default if you don't explicitly request leveldb). You'll need a resync to switch from hash scheme to path scheme since the database layout is completely swapped out, but you can keep your ancient's folder, so you should only need to download the state, not the chain history.

I have done a full re-sync, so it defaulted to Pebble this time. 

Pebble, with default settings, still has the same problem:

```
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [09-03|10:55:06.857] Persisted trie from memory database      nodes=12,537,064          size=3.11GiB   time=2m17.37057679s  gcnodes=42,619,946 gcsize=16.42GiB  gctime=7m11.203146194s livenodes=421,604 livesize=153.18MiB
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [09-03|10:55:06.862] Imported new potential chain segment     number=18,055,501 hash=e0afe6..e0ab82 blocks=1          txs=132           mgas=17.875  elapsed=42.728s       mgasps=0.418   dirty=195.33MiB
rocketpool_eth1        | DEBUG[09-03|10:55:06.865] Served engine_newPayloadV2               conn=172.18.0.4:55834 reqid=77173                     duration=42.759542431s
rocketpool_eth1        | INFO [09-03|10:55:06.884] Chain head was updated                   number=18,055,501 hash=e0afe6..e0ab82 root=3cf9ef..f13005 elapsed=21.74723ms
rocketpool_eth1        | DEBUG[09-03|10:55:06.978] Served engine_forkchoiceUpdatedV2        conn=172.18.0.4:55840 reqid=77175                     duration=34.655691173s
```


Is this `--state.scheme=path` also "default if you don't explicitly request leveldb", or is that something extra? If it's the latter, I misunderstood and only did a regular resync.

Also, if it is an extra flag, is this planned to be included in an upcoming Geth release? Would rather not switch to master for an issue that only shows up every few days.
--state.scheme=path is not default, so if you want to try that you need to redo it unfortunately
OK, will wait for a new Geth release that includes this option, and then do another resync.

Is this --state.scheme=path also "default if you don't explicitly request leveldb", or is that something extra? If it's the latter, I misunderstood and only did a regular resync.
Also, if it is an extra flag, is this planned to be included in an upcoming Geth release? Would rather not switch to master for an issue that only shows up every few days.

—Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.You are receiving this because you commented.Message ID: ***@***.***>

Can you speak to the chosen storage here? I am thinking it's borderline. I don't see these issues, is what I'm saying. If cloud, what storage was chosen? If hardware, make and model of the disk, and temperature as shown by smartctl -x? Anything else "in the path" that would slow storage down - VMs, Proxmox/ZFS, hardware RAID?

https://www.amazon.com/dp/B099RHVB42  (SK hynix Gold P31 2TB)

This one on a Radxa Rock 5B, equivalent to @jclapis 's popular EthereumOnArm setup. The lagspike is present immediately after `Persisted trie from memory database`, it's fast beyond that. Rocketpool Smartstack default installation, so Geth runs inside Docker.

Turn on `--log.vmodule rpc=5` to make the spike more visible. `Persisted trie from memory database` only occurs every ~3 days.
Make and model of the drive you are using with that 5B? What temperature does smartctl -x show for it?

SK hynix Gold P31 2TB

I don't think this will be any hardware issue in itself. When we flush a trie, a huge chunk of dirty node end up on disk. The database will have a hard time to shuffle all that data around for the next bit of time and will slow everything down. Also, all that dirty stuff gets flushed from RAM, so the cache misses will go down, needing more database reads - whilst the database is already thrashing itself on compaction. This mechanism does not happen on pathdb. I really think the nobrainer solution is to just leave this issue be since it's not a huge impact thing and switch to pathdb when it arrives in a couple weeks.

OK. My only comment is that the temp on that SSD is unusually high. I’ve seen it in the 40 range, so maybe an inexpensive heatsink or if it’s a fanless case a thermal pad can help.

I expect that at 68C it’s slowing down a bit.

And yes path based :).
Ah, 68 is indeed high :) That should be around the throttling temp. I have a similar issue in my setup where the SSD m2 slot is right under the GPU slot /facepalm
